comment_body: /azp run
Azure Pipelines successfully started running 1 pipeline(s).

@Junchao-Mellanox Can you please help in answering the below question in reference to the PR description?
```
In CmisManagerTask, it calls cmis.set_lpmode for each logical port. The time wait causes a wait_time * num_of_logical_port delay in link up time. The PR is to optimize it.
```

Question
1. From my understanding, the wait time should only apply to the first subport (specifically, the first subport to go through CMIS init for a breakout port group) of a physical port during CMIS initialization. For the remaining subports, the port should already be in high power mode, making the wait effectively a NOOP.
Is the goal of this PR to reduce CMIS initialization time by allowing subsequent logical ports to proceed without waiting for the high power mode transition?

2. Could you also share any performance metrics or stats that demonstrate the improvement from this change?
@prgeor kindly reminder to provide your feedback on this PR

> @prgeor kindly reminder to provide your feedback on this PR

@liat-grozovik waiting for answers to Mihirs question

> @Junchao-Mellanox Can you please help in answering the below question in reference to the PR description?
> 
> ```
> In CmisManagerTask, it calls cmis.set_lpmode for each logical port. The time wait causes a wait_time * num_of_logical_port delay in link up time. The PR is to optimize it.
> ```
> 
> Question
> 
> 1. From my understanding, the wait time should only apply to the first subport (specifically, the first subport to go through CMIS init for a breakout port group) of a physical port during CMIS initialization. For the remaining subports, the port should already be in high power mode, making the wait effectively a NOOP.
>    Is the goal of this PR to reduce CMIS initialization time by allowing subsequent logical ports to proceed without waiting for the high power mode transition?
> 2. Could you also share any performance metrics or stats that demonstrate the improvement from this change?

@mihirpat1 [1]. I think at present set_lpmode() is a busy wait function, which means when you have 8 subports, Cmis Mgr will wait for module to transition from `LpMode` -> `ModuelReady`. This PR is removing this busy wait and making use of `CMIS_STATE_AP_CONF` state where Xcvrd checks for `ModuleReady` in a non-busy way.

@Junchao-Mellanox We need to make sure

1. If module is transitioning from `LpMode` -> `ModuleReady` , and there is a set_lpmod(False) called again(breakout scenario), does that impact the ongoing transition?
2. If there is a timeout for `ModuleReady` , CMIS mgr does `force_cmis_reinit()`, can you confirm if this will eventually help to move the module to `ModuleReady` ?

Hi @mihirpat1 ,

Due my test, set_lpmode takes about 0.5s when there is wait. And it takes about 0.01s when there is no wait. After applying this change, the link up time for 512 ports saves 20 to 30 seconds. You are right about the subport: only the first subport executes the wait. But it still took 64 * 0.5 = ~32 seconds. Also, the idea is that we don't need this wait in set_lpmode function since CmisManagerTask has already done the wait in state machine.

> > @Junchao-Mellanox Can you please help in answering the below question in reference to the PR description?
> > ```
> > In CmisManagerTask, it calls cmis.set_lpmode for each logical port. The time wait causes a wait_time * num_of_logical_port delay in link up time. The PR is to optimize it.
> > ```
> > 
> > 
> >     
> >       
> >     
> > 
> >       
> >     
> > 
> >     
> >   
> > Question
> > 
> > 1. From my understanding, the wait time should only apply to the first subport (specifically, the first subport to go through CMIS init for a breakout port group) of a physical port during CMIS initialization. For the remaining subports, the port should already be in high power mode, making the wait effectively a NOOP.
> >    Is the goal of this PR to reduce CMIS initialization time by allowing subsequent logical ports to proceed without waiting for the high power mode transition?
> > 2. Could you also share any performance metrics or stats that demonstrate the improvement from this change?
> 
> @mihirpat1 [1]. I think at present set_lpmode() is a busy wait function, which means when you have 8 subports, Cmis Mgr will wait for module to transition from `LpMode` -> `ModuelReady`. This PR is removing this busy wait and making use of `CMIS_STATE_AP_CONF` state where Xcvrd checks for `ModuleReady` in a non-busy way.
> 
> @Junchao-Mellanox We need to make sure
> 
> 1. If module is transitioning from `LpMode` -> `ModuleReady` , and there is a set_lpmod(False) called again(breakout scenario), does that impact the ongoing transition?
> 2. If there is a timeout for `ModuleReady` , CMIS mgr does `force_cmis_reinit()`, can you confirm if this will eventually help to move the module to `ModuleReady` ?

Hi @prgeor ,

For the first question, I suppose it does not matter. If user set module to low power mode during the transitioning from `LpMode` -> `ModuleReady`, the busy wait does not help either. Because set_lpmod(False) could be called right after busy wait succesfully return.

For the second question, my test never hit the timeout for `ModuleReady`. It usually takes no more than 0.5s to reach `ModuleReady`. I think if we reach such timetout, the issue is on module side.

> > > @Junchao-Mellanox Can you please help in answering the below question in reference to the PR description?
> > > ```
> > > In CmisManagerTask, it calls cmis.set_lpmode for each logical port. The time wait causes a wait_time * num_of_logical_port delay in link up time. The PR is to optimize it.
> > > ```
> > > 
> > > 
> > >     
> > >       
> > >     
> > > 
> > >       
> > >     
> > > 
> > >     
> > >   
> > > Question
> > > 
> > > 1. From my understanding, the wait time should only apply to the first subport (specifically, the first subport to go through CMIS init for a breakout port group) of a physical port during CMIS initialization. For the remaining subports, the port should already be in high power mode, making the wait effectively a NOOP.
> > >    Is the goal of this PR to reduce CMIS initialization time by allowing subsequent logical ports to proceed without waiting for the high power mode transition?
> > > 2. Could you also share any performance metrics or stats that demonstrate the improvement from this change?
> > 
> > 
> > @mihirpat1 [1]. I think at present set_lpmode() is a busy wait function, which means when you have 8 subports, Cmis Mgr will wait for module to transition from `LpMode` -> `ModuelReady`. This PR is removing this busy wait and making use of `CMIS_STATE_AP_CONF` state where Xcvrd checks for `ModuleReady` in a non-busy way.
> > @Junchao-Mellanox We need to make sure
> > 
> > 1. If module is transitioning from `LpMode` -> `ModuleReady` , and there is a set_lpmod(False) called again(breakout scenario), does that impact the ongoing transition?
> > 2. If there is a timeout for `ModuleReady` , CMIS mgr does `force_cmis_reinit()`, can you confirm if this will eventually help to move the module to `ModuleReady` ?
> 
> Hi @prgeor ,
> 
> For the first question, I suppose it does not matter. If user set module to low power mode during the transitioning from `LpMode` -> `ModuleReady`, the busy wait does not help either. Because set_lpmod(False) could be called right after busy wait succesfully return.
> 
> For the second question, my test never hit the timeout for `ModuleReady`. It usually takes no more than 0.5s to reach `ModuleReady`. I think if we reach such timetout, the issue is on module side.

@Junchao-Mellanox [1] I am not looking for user perspective but during breakout scenario when the CMIS state machine is calling set_lpmode() N times for N-subports.
I will test and get back to you.

Hi @prgeor , there is no issue for following case.
```
If module is transitioning from LpMode -> ModuleReady , and there is a set_lpmod(False) called again(breakout scenario), does that impact the ongoing transition?
```

`set_lpmode(False)` does not change module state if module is already in high power.

Hi @ymd-arista , could you please add more details why we can't use the data in Chassis module table on redis_chassis.server? Please dd UT logs showing the dump of dbs etc.

@anamehra : Our understanding is that PHYSICAL_ENTITY_TABLE should basically be a mirror/staging area for everything that we export via SNMP as opposed to having SNMP having to look in multiple places for all of the info it needs.

DB dumps:

1. After adding some more fields about module to 'CHASSIS_MODULE_TABLE`

`CHASSIS_MODULE_TABLE|FABRIC-CARD0: {'desc': 'DCS-7804-FM', 'slot': '51', 'oper_status': 'Online', 'num_asics': '2', 'serial': 'SSN19430153', 'presence': 'True', 'is_replaceable': 'True', 'model': 'DCS-7804-FM'}`

`CHASSIS_MODULE_TABLE|LINE-CARD1: {'desc': 'Unknown', 'slot': '4', 'oper_status': 'Empty', 'num_asics': '0', 'serial': 'N/A', 'presence': 'False', 'is_replaceable': 'True', 'model': 'N/A'}`

2. After adding information about module to `PHYSICAL_ENTITY_INFO`

`root@nfc405:/home/admin# sonic-db-cli STATE_DB hgetall "PHYSICAL_ENTITY_INFO|fan5/1"
{'position_in_parent': '1', 'parent_name': 'FABRIC-CARD5'}`

`root@nfc405:/home/admin# sonic-db-cli STATE_DB hgetall "PHYSICAL_ENTITY_INFO|FABRIC-CARD5"
{'position_in_parent': '6', 'parent_name': 'chassis 1', 'serial': 'SSN20420826', 'model': '7808R3-FM', 'is_replaceable': 'True'}`

> @vvolam Not sure if it is supposed to be handled by the reboot feature implementation, but don't we need the same warning suppression if DPU is powered off as well? As the PCI id is removed even for powered off DPUs

@gpunathilell Noted. As this PR is avoiding the warnings logs based on the PCI entry in STATE_DB. We need to add this STATE_DB entry for the DPUs which are in power-off state. I will raise a separate PR for addressing this. Thank you!

  • :white_check_mark: login: ishidawataru / name: Wataru Ishida (7639be71212c69fb807f1f8d1434d0017d5e311a, 824d0594074b3c0a1ffd435ee4ee863d08b25e82, 33566ec63496856acb83a54bd83217748b752aea, 95ae842f65441d7c713c40d68f71a9139322160e)
@ishidawataru Can you please fix the code coverage check failure?
@mihirpat1 I'm still communicating with the original reporter of this issue to check the fix actually works. After that I'll fix the code coverage failure.
@mihirpat1 Confirmed that the fix resolved the issue. Also, I fixed the coverage test failure. Please review.

@prgeor This PR fixes https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/issues/18893. It is not about the application selection. The current `CmisManagerTask` implementation doesn't delete the port info from `port_dict` when ports are deleted due to DPB configuration, which causes a crash.

@longhuan-cisco @mihirpat1 I updated the PR based on @longhuan-cisco 's suggestion. Please review.

I used force-push and removed the original commits. I backed up the original branch [here](https://github.com/ishidawataru/sonic-platform-daemons/tree/fix-xcvrd-dpb-bak).
@prgeor Hi, just a gentle ping to check if I need to do something to get this PR merged.
/azp run
Azure Pipelines successfully started running 1 pipeline(s).
@prgeor I fixed the conflicts. Please take a look.
@ishidawataru will you be able to test this on a real hardware with breakout enabled and do insertion and removal of the optics?

@prgeor Sorry, I don’t have access to real hardware to test this PR. I performed insertion and removal testing using the xcvr emulator in last October. I can redo those tests and provide the logs if needed.

@prgeor 

I have done OIR tests with the latest diff. 

Tried below sequence on 400G AOC:
1. Move from non-breakout mode (1x400G) to 4x100G breakout mode via DPB CLI
2. Perform OIR
3. Move back to non-breakout mode (1x400G) via DPB CLI
4. Perform OIR

No xcvrd crash. link comes up fine with module ready state. `show interface` CLI shows correct interface entries.

```

PSU    Model         Serial         HW Rev  Voltage (V)    Current (A)    Power (W)    Status    LED
-----  ------------  -----------  --------  -------------  -------------  -----------  --------  -----
PSU0   PSU650W-ACPE  LIT241955UQ      0.00  11.996         24.0           288.0        OK        green
PSU1   PSU650W-ACPE  LIT241956QK      0.00  N/A            N/A            N/A          NOT OK    off
```
This is with the get_name API overwritten to raise NotImplemented for PSUs:
```
root@mth64-m5-2:/home/cisco# show plat psu
PSU    Model         Serial         HW Rev  Voltage (V)    Current (A)    Power (W)    Status    LED
-----  ------------  -----------  --------  -------------  -------------  -----------  --------  -----
PSU 1  PSU650W-ACPE  LIT241955UQ      0.00  11.98          24.0           288.0        OK        green
PSU 2  PSU650W-ACPE  LIT241956QK      0.00  N/A            N/A            N/A          NOT OK    off
```
The only functional difference between the two is the key/naming
